The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs(Previous called the attention of the Cabinet to telegramsReference:Cabinet 39 that had been circulated in regard to the desire of(89), Con-clusion 4(a).) Nahas Pasha, the Leader of the Wafd in Egypt, toinclude in the next Egyptian Cabinet Messrs AhmedMaher and Nokraski, and the objections urged by theBritish High Commissioner in Egypt against theinclusion of these two gentlemen, whose acquittal,by a majority of Egyptian Judges, on charges ofin the seriesmurder/which culminated in the assassination ofSir Lee Stack, had led to the resignation of theBritish Judge engaged in the case, notwithstanding that he thereby forfeited his pension rights, onwhich his livelihood and that of his wife and family depended. The Secretary of State read thedraft of a telegram supporting the High Commission-erTs attitude and confirming previous instructions.The Cabinet agreed (a) To endorse the policy of theSecretary of State for ForeignAffairs in the above matter:(b) To associate themselves withthe Secretary of State in histhanks to the Lord Presidentof the Council and the Secretaryof State for Air for their defenceof the government's Egyptian policyin the recent Debate in the Houseof Lords . EAST AFRICA.C Policy in.(previous reference:Cabinet 50(29), Con-clusxon IfcC)Q.2. The Cabinet had before them, in addition tothe documents considered at their previous Meeting,a Note by the Secretary of State for the Colonies(Paper CP.-360 (29)) covering the following:-(i) A statement of Native Policy whichit is proposed to publish as a white paper and to communicate to the governors of the territories con-cerned for their information and guidance.(ii) A Commentary, preceded by a Forewordin the Secretary of State's own name,on the position arising out of theReports of the Hilton Young Commis-sion and of Sir Samuel Wilson, whichthe Secretary of State proposed,with the approval of the Cabinet, to publish and lay before the proposedJoint Committee of both Houses ofParliament as a basis for their discussions.The proposal that had been formulated at theMeeting referred to in the margin, that a JointCommittee of both Houses should be asked to considerthe Hilton Young and the Samuel Wilson Reports,accompanied by a reasoned commentary of an informa-tive character as well as by a Declaration on native policy, no longer commended itself to the cabinet when considered in the light of the Secretary ofState's Memoranda, and there was general agreement that a further effort should be made by the cabinet itself to agree on a policy. It was accordingly decided That a Cabinet Committee, composedof -The Lord. Chancellor (In the Chair),The Secretary of State for theColonies,The Secretary of State for India,The Secretary of State for Air -should examine th*fc documents circulatedby the Secretary of State for the colonies and advise the Cabinet as tc the policy they should adopt, directing their attention more particularly to thetwo following points:-- p,- (i) Whether there should be a newofficer appointed whose duties would be to supervise Kenya,Tanganyika and Uganda (a Governor-General or a High Commissioner)and what should be his functions and powers in relation to thethree Governments which among them exercise jurisdiction over that area:(ii) Assuming such an officer beappointed, what alteration, ifany, should be made in the compo-sition of the Kenya LegislativeCouncil? e placing opfaths onoreign warmortals.[previous reference:Cabinet 34(28), Con-clusxon 9 .)3. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum bythe Ministers at the head of the three service departments (Pa,;-er CP.-358 (29)) circulating, forinformation, a Memorandum submitted by their predecessors-successors in office,, in which it was suggested thatthe time had now come for discontinuing the practiceof placing wreaths on foreign war memorials and official participation in all such ceremonies abroad.The three Service Ministers expressed agreement inthe views of their predecessors and recommended thatthe practice referred to should be discontinued.The Cabinet agreed That the Secretary of State forForeign Affairs, without at thisstage formally proposing the discontinuance of the abovepractices, should take such steps as he might deem appro-priate to sound foreign nations on the subject, with a view todiscontinuance if the replieswere favourable. *THE OOALMINES DILL,1929.(previous reference:Cabinet 50(29), Con-elusion 5.)4. The Prime Minister consulted his colleagues as to whether the Committee Stage of the Coal mines bill should be taken on the floor of the House ofCommons or, in order to save Parliamentary time,should be sent to Committee.upstairs.This led to a discussion on parliamentary procedure, which is referred to in the followingMinute.As regards the Coal Mines Bill it was agreed (a) That, so far as could be judged from present information, the Bill wouldhave to be taken on the floor of theHouse:(b) That the President of the Board ofTrade should indicate to the PrimeMinister his views as to the Parlia-mentary time-table for the Coal mines bill.(For the position of the Coal vines Billin the Parliamentary time-table see alsothe Conclusions in. the following Minute.) 5. In the course of the discussion on the CoalMines Bill referred to in the previous conclusion the Prime Minister gave his colleagues a forecast of the Parliamentary time-table between January andthe Summer Adjournment, and emphasised the limited amount of time available for new legislation.During the discussion various suggestions weremade: e.g., a shortening of the Laster Recess:also that the Opposition Parties might be induced toagree to allow even the larger measures of the session to be discussed in Committee, and that, ifthe latter course were followed, the Rules wouldhave to be altered to prevent the blocking of bills in Committee by an excess of amendments, examples of which were given. There was general agreement that the question of Slum Clearance would have to bedealt with in the present Session of Parliament.The Prime Minister undertook to circulate tohis colleagues a. digest of the information he had communicated to them in regard to the time-table forthe remainder of the Session, and invited all to regard it as a specially confidential document.The Cabinet agreed (a) That the question of the time-tableshould be considered at one of aseries of Meetings to be commencedon Tuesday, January 14, 1930:* . f,b)-LThat the Prime Minister should aim^rw-^ll^^^S^^^J^r^aotlonJ^of the Coal mines bill early in the tnird y/eek of theParliamentary Session of 1930:(e) That during the first two weeks ofthe Parliamentary Session of 1930the Prime Minister should endeavourto provide for the discussion of the supplementary Estimates required inconnection with the UnemploymentInsurance Pill:(d) That the Leader of the House of lords should endeavour to secure the passageof the Unemployment Insurance Billby the House of Lords in time for theabove programme to be carried out. THE SALE OPARMS ANDAMMUNITION.(previous reference:Cabinet 43(29), Con-clusion 2.)6 . The Cabinet had before them the following documents relating to the disposal of surplusmunitions to foreign countries:-A Memorandum by the Secretary ofState for War (Paper CP.-361 (29))asking for decisions on the follow-ing questions of doubt in regard tothe application of the cabinet decisions 42 (29) 7 and 43 (29) 2,viz:-(i) An application from the LatvianLegation representing that theLatvian army is almost entirelyequipped with British arms andenquiring whether a request from them to purchase from time totime arms and accessories fromBritish surplus stocks would be permitted:(ii) An application from the SoleyArmament Company, Limited, to export warlike stores to Latvia:(iii) An application from Latvia andcertain other countries whichhave purchased munitions direct from the War Office in the pastto be supplied with spare partsof the weapons they havepurchased.A Memorandum by the President of theBoard of Trade (Paper CP.-363 (29))asking for a clear definition of theduties of the Board of Trade withregard to the issue of Export licences and suggesting that, in view of the elaborate enquiries which are alreadyinstituted before an Export Licenceis issued, the Board should be relieved of the duty of making further enquires as to the source of the arms ; in other words, that if the Departments con-suited raise no objection to the Boardof Trade issuing a licence in a parti-cular case the Board should issue it without further enquiry. attention was also drawn to the fact that whereBritish surplus arris are purchased by foreign Governments there is a naturaltendency for them to come to us forammunition, which is important fromthe point of view of trade and employ-ment.The Cabinet agreed (a) That His Majesty's Government shouldnot dispose of surplus munitions and arms to foreign Governments:(b) That this should not debar a gift bythe Government of India to Afghanistan. EXPORT CREDITSAND RUSSIA.(previous reference:Cabinet 30(29), Con-conclusion 2.)7 . The Cabinet had before then, a Memorandum bythe President o:" the Board of Trade(Paper C.P.-362(29)) asking for guidance from the Cabinet as tothe course the Board should take on the subject ofthe grant of credit facilities for Russian business,in which, after a survey or? the whole question, itwas recommended that the present moment, on the eveof the Russian negotiations, is unpropitious for extending in Russia the activities of the credits guarantee Department, and that that department should not be instructed at present to give longcredits to Russia.The Cabinet agreed - That the Credits Guarantee department should not be instructed at present to grant long credits to Russia. retirement pensions.(previous reference:Cabinet 51(29), Con-elusion 4.)8, The First Lord of the Admiralty reportedthat he had hoped to be in a position to circulate to the Cabinet a Report on Retirement Pensions,but this had proved impossible as an unexpecteddifficulty had arisen at the last moment. TheCommittee were to meet on the following afternoon,when he hoped the final Report would be settled. THE factories bill .9. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum bythe Home Secretary (Paper CP.-364 (29)) covering-a further draft of the Factories Bill revised inaccordance with the decisions of the Cabinet and proposing, subject to any further observations hiscolleagues might have to make, to give notice tointroduce the Till in the present week. In thisMemorandum it was pointed out that under the new clause 72 the sole purpose for which overtime isto be allowed in any industry or process is thatof enabling pressure of work to be dealt with, andthen only when the extension of hours contemplated by the Clause is recognised by collective agreementor by award as to wages and conditions, or asauthorised by Order of the Secretary of State:further, that, in view of sub-clause (4) of Clause156, that the provision of the Factories Bill shallbe in addition to and not in substitution for ordiminution of any other Act, there could he noquestion of the provisions of Clause 72 operating in derogation of the Hours of Employment Act.After ascertaining that the Lord Chancellor andthe Lord President of the Council agreed with theHome Secretary that the provisions of the factories bill complied with the Washington Hours Convention,the Cabinet authorised the Home Secretary to intrd-duce the Factories Bill in the form contained in paper C.P.-36c( (29) .(previous reference:Cabinet 52(29), Con-clusion 6 .) 10.
